author: sky.cactus
content: <@552133098075193354> (or anyone else who knows) is there a high level "specification" (the more human readable the better) for withdraws that is relatively up to date with current thinking?

author: sky.cactus
content: I know there is the EL EIP, and the CL PR.  I was hoping for something more like an architecture overview that links to those documents and is more consumable by a broader audience.

author: m.kalinin
content:

Not sure how representative it is for broader audience and not sure whether it is up to date or not, cc <@539495253418180618>

author: potuz
content: There were some notes written by Danny a long ago that were linked in the CL specs. They were nicely written for everyone I think. Probably they are not up to date in technical details like the queue, but that's not important from an end-user perspective

author: Deleted User
content: https://twitter.com/polarpunklabs/status/1597207420027011072

author: Deleted User
content: Academic article that discusses Ethereum + a summary of development, dev culture, etc.

author: Deleted User
content: Namechecks a few of you guys, so hopefully of some meta-intrigue!

author: Deleted User
content: 'This paper inquires into the dynamic imaginaries of the Ethereum project. We present Ethereum as animated by three such imaginaries: the world computer (technical), productive money (economic) and public goods (political). We examine how these imaginaries are materialized, carried forward and evolve through the Ethereum ecosystem, focusing on how Ethereum’s prefigurative logic underpins this dynamism. In our analysis, we pay particular attention to how the imaginaries overlap and often generate contradictions that nonetheless do not seem to undermine the cohesion of the project. We introduce the concept of ‘prefigurative imaginaries’ to describe how prefiguration works to create multiple, mutually entangled but distinct imaginaries.'

author: potuz
content: you'll have a better chance of anyone reading it if you post it on the arxiv.  Most people in technical research institutions won't have access to an obscure journal "Social Epistemology "
